title: 105_s357
content: The Act may be cited as the "Grand Staircase-Escalante Resource Protection Act". Congress finds that the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument applies only to Federal land within its boundary, and multiple use is the guiding principle for public land management. The Monument should remain open for multiple uses, and Federal water rights in the Monument should be in accordance with Utah state laws. The Act should not impair Utah's water rights or mining revenues from Federal and State School lands. The creation of the Monument in Utah must not harm the state's school children by causing a loss of mining revenues and royalties, without proper consultation with Congress, State, and local authorities. The failure to establish a specific boundary for the Monument may lead to disputes requiring boundary adjustments. The curr_chunk is a section header "SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT OF THE MONUMENT. The Monument shall be managed as a special management area by the Secretary, following principles of multiple use and sustained yield for various resources, protection of resources, and economic sustainability for local communities. The Secretary delegates management authority to the Director for the Monument, with the Bureau of Land Management as the lead agency. Future actions may include revocation of the Proclamation by Congress or Executive order, but the Monument must be managed according to this Act as long as it remains designated as a national monument. SEC. 5. VALID EXISTING RIGHTS AND USES. The Secretary must respect valid existing rights, leases, permits, and authorizations under various laws, including the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and the General Mining Law of 1872. The Secretary must respect valid existing rights, leases, permits, and authorizations under various laws, including the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and the General Mining Law of 1872. The designation of the Monument or the management plan shall not restrict valid existing rights exercised in compliance with applicable laws. The Secretary shall permit routine roads and rights-of-way. The Secretary must respect valid existing rights, leases, permits, and authorizations under various laws. Roads and rights-of-way within Monument boundaries are permitted for maintenance and improvement. Any valid existing right taken due to Monument designation shall be compensated by the Secretary. Range management within the Monument allows for continued grazing of livestock without curtailment. Existing grazing leases and permits are unaffected by the Monument designation. The Secretary cannot require permittees or lessees to transfer water rights as a condition for grazing permits or leases. Existing withdrawals, reservations, and appropriations can only be revoked in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act. There is no federal reservation of water rights within the Monument. The Act does not create any federal reservation of water rights in the United States. The United States can acquire water rights in the Monument according to Utah law. These rights can only be exercised in accordance with Utah law, and eminent domain is not authorized by the Act. The Act does not authorize the use of eminent domain by the United States to acquire water rights within the Monument. It also does not affect the capacity, operation, or maintenance of water facilities within or outside the Monument. Additionally, it does not limit access to Federal land for development projects. The Act does not authorize eminent domain for acquiring water rights within the Monument and does not affect water facilities' capacity, operation, or maintenance. It also does not limit access to Federal land for development projects, including water resource projects. SEC. 9. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary must submit a management plan for the Monument to Congress by September 18, 1999, following the principles of multiple use and sustained yield. The plan should address the responsible use of all Monument resources in a systematic interdisciplinary approach. The management plan for the Monument must address the responsible use of resources in compliance with laws and public input. Development and utilization of resources are allowed if deemed in the national interest or during a national emergency. Within 45 days of enactment, existing guidelines must be modified to meet the requirements of the Act. The Monument's management must comply with the Act's requirements. Pending lease applications on Monument land will not expire if the Secretary has not acted on them. SEC. 10 of the Act clarifies that it does not affect Utah's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife management. SEC. 11 addresses a school trust lands exchange. The Secretary will expedite exchanges of school trust lands within the Monument, value school trust land sections based on mineral development potential, analyze lost Federal royalties, and ensure access to State sections within the Monument. Exchanges of school trust lands within the Monument will be expedited by the Secretary, involving agencies of the State of Utah and designated permittees. SEC. 12. ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The Secretary shall establish the "Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument Advisory Committee" within 90 days of this Act. The committee will advise on Monument resources, State school trust lands, and consist of various members including the Secretary, Governor of Utah, and appointed individuals. The "Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument Advisory Committee" will be established by the Secretary within 90 days of the Act, with members recommended by the Governor of Utah representing various interests and agencies, local communities, Native Americans, and the public at large. The advisory committee will have 1 public representative and members serving 5-year terms, with the option for reappointment. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The committee will select a chairperson, meet regularly, and require a majority for a quorum. Members will serve without compensation but can be reimbursed for travel expenses. The advisory committee operates in accordance with section 5703 of title 5, United States Code. The Monument planning team for the management plan must include at least 5 persons appointed by the Governor of Utah. Appropriations are authorized for various purposes including management plans, protection of resources, visitor services, law enforcement, public safety, payments to impacted counties, economic mitigation, and operation of the advisory committee.
